Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an SEM with EDS elemental analysis and STEM detector for Research and Education at Hofstra University and Nassau Community College
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Hofstra University for the purchase of an analytical scanning electron microscope (SEM) with three vacuum modes (including extended vacuum mode - ESEM), Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectrometer (EDS), and Scanning Transmission Electron Microscope (STEM) detector. Faculty will use this new SEM for research and training across disciplines at Hofstra University (including researchers from the Division of Natural Sciences and the School of Engineering and Applied Sciences) and by faculty from the Department of Biology at Nassau Community College. In total, 14 Hofstra faculty members and their students among five disciplines (Biology, Chemistry, Engineering, Geology, and Physics) and Biology faculty from Nassau Community College will be the major users of the equipment. The grant will also support the research endeavors of two Academic Centers at Hofstra University: the Center for Climate Study and the Center for Condensed Matter Research. Specifically, the equipment will allow this interdisciplinary group of faculty and their students to carry out research activities such as the following: 1) impacts of nutrients on the regulation of physiology and metabolism in Drosophila, 2) improving crop yield in cotton through the study of factors affecting the conversion of epidermal cells to fibers, 3) exploration of chemical mechanisms involved in aluminum corrosion, and 4) investigating the ultrastructure and functional morphology of polychaete worms and parasitic isopods. All of these represent long-standing questions within the fields of the researchers.

Acquisition of the new SEM will strengthen Hofstra's (a Primarily Undergraduate Institution) ongoing efforts in basic research, thus supporting the University's mission to foster excellence in scholarly research and teaching. In addition, the acquired SEM would support the collaboration with faculty from Nassau Community College (NCC, the largest single-campus community college in NY with >40% of the students representing ethnic minorities). This new SEM will allow the PIs to increase their recruitment of well-qualified students from the pool of under-represented groups through established programs such as the Collegiate Science and Technology Entry Program (designed to increase the number of historically under-represented students in the sciences). Studies enabled by this SEM will provide a wide range of societal benefits, such as a better understanding of: fat storage in model organisms (with implications on human biology), crop yield in cotton, aluminum corrosion, and the evolutionary history of parasitic isopods (including those of commercially important hosts). Public outreach from the research will include professional development workshops (administered through the Institute for the Development of Education in the Advanced Sciences at Hofstra), during which local college and high school educators will be trained in the applications of SEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds from this Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant supported the establishment of an Electron Microscope facility at Hofstra University through the purchase of an analytical Scanning Electron Microscope and associated equipment including an Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectrometer (EDS) for elemental analysis of specimens. This new facility has been used by faculty in research and training across disciplines at Hofstra University (including researchers from the Division of Natural Sciences and the School of Engineering and Applied Sciences) and by faculty from the Department of Biology at Nassau Community College. In total, 13 Hofstra faculty members and their undergraduate and graduate students among four disciplines (Biology, Chemistry, Engineering, and Geology) were the major users of the equipment. In addition, the equipment has led to collaborations between faculty from Hofstra and three other institutions. Specifically, the equipment enabled this interdisciplinary group of faculty and students to carry out research activities on topics including, for example: 1) impacts of nutrients on the regulation of physiology and metabolism in fruit flies, 2) chemical mechanisms involved in aluminum corrosion, 3) ultrastructure and functional morphology of parasitic isopods, and 4) differentiation of mesenchymal cells. Establishment of the new EM facility has strengthened Hofstra's ongoing efforts in basic research, thus supporting the University’s mission to foster excellence in scholarly research and teaching. Students were trained in the use of the SEM during several techniques-based courses at Hofstra and Nassau Community College. In total, over 50 Hofstra undergraduate students, graduate students, and high school researchers (as part of the Hofstra University Summer Science Research Program) have completed research projects with the new equipment. Thirteen of these students have completed theses (BA, BS or MS) based on work with the SEM at Hofstra University. To date, six papers have been published and include data or images collected with the equipment and several others are being prepared for submission. The PIs and students have disseminated their work through presentations at over 20 local, national, or international meetings. Most of these presentations were made by students or included students as co-authors. Finally, images from the electron microscope are highlighted on freely available websites, engaging the public in some of our results and exposing them to research conducted with EM technologies. At Hofstra, results from work on the SEM have been presented as part of two lecture series in order to make the public, particularly K-12 educators, aware of our work and its implications.
